headline: Tyrrell Hatton admits 'I'm just glad it's all over' as the English hothead can't hide his anger after finishing SEVENTEEN over par at the Masters
author: Riath Al-Samarrai for the Daily Mail
sentences:
+4
View gallery
The 30-year-old Englishman described the most revered strip of land in his sport as 'unfair'
While there is little doubting that Hatton has the talent to contend at majors, and certainly has the iron play and putting to do well at the Masters, it seems equally obvious that a time is approaching when he needs to get out of his own way.

+4
View gallery
Talented Northern Irishman Rory McIlroy (above) is likely to finish the leading British player
His driving had been woeful to that point, so his frustration was demonstrated by slamming his club into the tee box — they take a dim view of all that at Augusta National.

Going in some kind of order, he appeared to flick a middle finger at the green on the first, which he bogeyed, he swore after his putt veered right of the cup on three — another bogey — and then had moment on the fifth.
Hatton, ranked 16 in the world remember, is sufficiently aware of those shortcomings that he even parodied it in a brilliant anger management sketch for the European Tour last year.
His tee shot had the good fortune to land between the two fairway bunkers down the left, but his second caught a slope at the back of the green and ran a long way to trouble.
He had doubled the modified 11th after overruling the instruction of his caddie Mick Donaghy to go with a five iron for his second shot, instead sending a six into the water.
By the time he was done swinging, he sat 17 over par and last among the weekend field of 52, with flashpoints of anger on the course outnumbering his birdies by five to one.
Even by his standards for rage, which are considerably higher than most, he cut a desperately frustrated figure for most of the 80 blows he needed to wrap up his tournament.
Another bogey at nine took Hatton to the turn in 38 — he had picked up his sole birdie at the second — before a minor hell played out on the entry and exits of Amen Corner.
Among other actions he took on Sunday, his words will no doubt agitate the more curmudgeonly followers of golf, and quite possibly a few of the more mild-mannered as well.
If conventional wisdom would have it that bright flowers and a good walk are food for the soul, then spend a few hours watching and listening to Tyrrell Hatton at Augusta.
He closed on one over with a 73 for a tie of 12th, while Lee Westwood and Matt Fitzpatrick climbed to two over with respective sub-par rounds of one and two under.

+4
View gallery
Hothead Tyrrell Hatton (above) could not hide his anger at the Augusta Masters Tournament
Give it to Hatton, he is never dull.
'It's just one of those weeks that I feel like if I come back in the future, it's just a case of trying to get through the best that I can.
To think he was still in something of a hump when he walked off and described the most revered strip of land in his sport as 'unfair'.
After another bogey at 15 he tossed his ball away, before signing off with a final dropped shot at the last and a face like thunder.
Fast-rising Scot Robert MacIntyre, who has made eight cuts from his first eight majors, finished with a 69 for three over.
Meanwhile, Danny Willett, had an uplifting experience at the Masters after the difficulties that followed his win in 2016.
His only objective through that torturous final loop, he said, was 'getting off the course as fast as possible'.
But there is still a noted difference between recognising the flaw and fixing it, which was glaringly apparent.
There is the question of when Hatton, now 30, will fire again in more meaningful ways at a major.
Tommy Fleetwood joined them on two over with a 73, with the trio finishing inside the top 15.
Standing in a fury, he could be heard saying to his caddie: 'I hate this place.'
And he then fired a seven at 13, after a lost ball off the tee.
This truly was not one of the days when he kept a lid on it.
You can hit good shots here and not get any reward.
Sacrilege to some; eminently relatable to others.
It's unfair at times — I don't agree with that.'
'I think that's a pretty good way to sum it up.
It's a scenario fit for the busting of myths.
This course doesn't really suit my eye.
Then came his words for the media.
'I'm glad it's over,' he said.
I just never do well here.
